title: Argument
content:
Overview

  • A statement of fact, an assertion, or a claim (either a positive claim or a negative claim)
  • A formal argument statement (containing premises and a conclusion)
  • An argument's title should convey as clearest and concise as possible the gist or conclusion of the argument, no kicking around the bush.

Elements

  • Title
  • Content
  • Comment -- contextual content that links it to the parent
  • Reference Date
  • ScreeningStatus

Types of Argument

  • A truth or reality argument (deductive or non-deductive)
    • An extrapolation argument (non-deductive: inductive or abductive)
    • A historical argument (non-deductive, consider combining to Extrapolation)
  • A moral or ethical argument - this type does not claim a truth or reality but is an ethical claim. The conclusion for this comes from user voting which sums the general consensus based on human nature.
  • A testimony of an experience - the conclusion of this argument comes from the profile of the claimant/s and consistency of the claim. Other users may claim to have experienced the same and will be asked to add a comment to state the account. Reviewers may add a verdict on how believable or sensible is the claim.
  • A reference material or asset - should we make this a separate entity type?
    • A public material (a popular claim) - meaning this argument or statement is popular so keeping it intact to discuss its issues and facts
    • A reference material

Correlation to parent topic or argument

  • For, supporting, in agreement
  • Against, opposing, in disagreement

Tags

  • Contains moral or ethical value
  • A statistical data
  • Prediction / Retrodiction (huge extrapolation)
  • Leap of faith (?)
  • Negative assertion/claim
  • Historical
  • Generalization/Approximation (non-deductive)

Possible Issues

  • Composite argument - An entry containing multiple independent claims not representing a primary claim or argument; except for public material
  • Misleading argument - implying it has presented the complete picture and presents a conclusion event if that is not the case.
  • Logical fallacy (formal or informal, invalid)
    • Extreme or false generalization - example: After showing a video about addiction, it concludes or say: Everything we know about addiction is wrong.
  • Biased
